thread.title: When is the lunar eclipse 2017? How to watch tonight’s snow moon eclipse and GREEN comet
thread.title_full: When is the lunar eclipse 2017? How to watch tonight’s snow moon eclipse and GREEN comet

author: Yahoo News UK
title: When is the lunar eclipse 2017? How to watch tonight’s snow moon eclipse and GREEN comet
text:
View photos
The green-tinged New Year comet can be spotted in the early hours of Saturday morning (NASA/JPL/Caltech) More This evening’s night sky will be packed with celestial treats for stargazers, including a lunar eclipse and a bizarre green comet.
The Earth’s shadow is set to fall on the snow moon – a full moon that falls in February – tonight (Friday 10 February).
This lunar event will then be followed by the appearance of a green-tinged comet, also known as the New Year Comet.
When is the lunar eclipse?
The penumbral lunar eclipse will be visible for people in the UK from around 10.30 tonight as the sun, moon and Earth all line up.
This will cast a dark shadow across the lunar surface, rather than obscuring the moon completely, as a total eclipse would.
It is expected to reach its peak at around 12.45am on Saturday morning.
View photos
A previous lunar eclipse viewed through passing clouds (Design Pics Inc/REX/Shutterstock) More What is the New Year Comet?
Named 45P/Honda-Mrkos-Pajdušáková, the emerald green comet passes close enough to Earth to be seen every five and a quarter years.
First spotted in 1948, the comet is named after the three astronomers that discovered it – Minoru Honda, Antonín Mrkos, and Ľudmila Pajdušáková.
It has also been named the New Year Comet as it began its journey across Northern Hemisphere skies shortly before the end of 2016.
The unusual tint is the result of evaporating diatomic carbon, which shows up green in space.
When is the best time to see the comet?
The 45P comet will be closest to Earth at 8.00am on the morning of Saturday 11 February, however, those hoping to catch a glimpse of it should head out well before the sun rises at 7am.
“It’ll be visible in the morning sky in the constellation Hercules. The comet then passes through the constellations Corona Borealis (the Northern Crown), Boötes (the Herdsman), Canes Venatici (Boötes’ hunting dogs) and Ursa Major,” according to NASA.
MORE: Eight strange signs that you’re more intelligent than average
MORE: 10 tips to make your iPhone battery last longer
The comet won’t be visible to the naked eye, but can be spotted with a telescope or binoculars. Those hoping to see it will have a better chance by staying away from the light pollution of buildings and street lights in urban areas.
The comet will return in 2022.
